3.topCaption: TOP: Precast, fully formed chimneys were placed on top of the new colleges’ bare structural framing, leading observers to wonder if they would serve any purpose.
3.bottomCaption: LEFT: Franklin College Chimney Key Plan by RAMSA, Courtesy of Yale, colored by author. The two new colleges have 45 chimneys of 19 different designs, six serve fireplace hearths, and 33 of which serve air handling functions.
paragraphs: The sight of fully-formed, brick-and-stone chimneys resting atop the bare structural frame of Franklin and Murray Colleges during their construction drew stares and speculation from passersby during the winter of 2015-2016. “What’s with the chimneys?” was the spoken or unspoken question. Were they just for show? Would they be connected to fireplaces? Should they be seen as gratuitous “follies,” a sign of pretensions on the part of either the architect or the university, or both?

Here are the facts about those mysterious chimneys: The two new colleges combined have 45 chimneys, designed by RAMSA in a series of 19 different types. Six of them serve fireplace hearths in the head-of-college houses and the common areas adjacent to the dining halls. Six more are purely decorative after all. And the remaining 33 are connected to the colleges’ air handling equipment in the attic, devoted either to taking in fresh air or venting out exhaust air.

2.topCaption: TOP: Chimneys accentuate the roofline of Yale’s Collegiate Gothic residential colleges such as Calhoun (1933), designed by John Russell Pope.
2.title: HOT AIR ON HIGH
2.bottomCaption: LEFT: A sculptural chimney profile on Trumbull College (1933), Yale, designed by James Gamble Rogers.
paragraphs: What’s with All the Chimneys?

Look up at Yale’s medievalizing buildings, past the empty niches and lancet windows, above the stone coping and zinc gutters, and your eyes alight upon a chimney—then another, and another, and if you don’t look away soon your eyes will be gliding effortlessly across the roofscape as if chasing Mary Poppins’s shadow.

Sculptural chimneys—along with slender finials and stout turrets—are the among the vertical accoutrements that accentuate Yale’s characteristic rooflines. These forms were originally meant to evoke Oxford and Cambridge Universities in England, but today are just as emblematic of Yale itself, not to mention Harry Potter’s Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.

5.topCaption: TOP: The chimney units were delivered by truck and placed by crane. Pictured here is the base of chimney type C (scroll down for a view taken after installation).
5.bottomCaption: LEFT: The chimneys, fabricated in Quebec, have a cast concrete core surrounded by brick from Pennsylvania, limestone from Indiana, and granite trim from Massachusetts, matching the façades.
paragraphs: As for fabrication, the fact that the chimneys were craned into place indicates they were built offsite or “precast” in a factory. But the many design variations indicate that this was no ordinary manufacturing job. In fact, the Quebec-based manufacturer Béton préfabriqué du Lac (BPDL) combined handcrafted masonry with efficient production techniques to build Franklin and Murray’s 45 custom-designed chimneys.

The core of each chimney is essentially a concrete tube. The chimney exteriors, however, are finished with the exact same brick (a three-color blend from Pennsylvania) and stone (limestone from Indiana and granite from Massachusetts) used throughout the building façades. BPDL received shipments of these materials and placed them in the specified patterns around the concrete core so as to form integrally cast units that could be hoisted straight into place. What appears to be mortar between the bricks is actually concrete tinted to match the mortar used on the façades.

4.topCaption: TOP: Chimney types A (right) and J (left) of Murray College connect with ductwork beneath the roof.
4.bottomCaption: LEFT: The four chimneys above the future Resident Fellows house of Franklin College are purely decorative.
paragraphs: So most of the chimneys do serve a material purpose after all, and they keep the roofscape clear of unsightly mechanical and ventilation equipment.. But there is no way to tell from the outside which function the chimneys serve, and that is partly because they are designed to serve a more intangible purpose—that of providing distinctive visual cues to carve a large complex into smaller, more intimate places. Each building and courtyard is supposed to have its own quirks, with which students may come to identify over time.

6.topCaption: TOP: The undulating form of RAMSA’s new chimney type C atop Franklin College recalls the 1933 Trumbull chimney pictured above.
6.bottomCaption: LEFT: The precast chimney, which handles air exchange, is designed to look seamless with the façade masonry below. Elevation drawing by RAMSA, Courtesy of Yale.
paragraphs: The result of all this effort is that the chimneys appear to have been constructed by masons on the roof, when in fact they were fabricated in a controlled factory setting, saving valuable time on site. Is it deceptive? Yes, a little. Does that make them fake? No. The combination of sleight-of-hand with creative ambition and technical expediency are deeply ingrained in Yale’s Collegiate Gothic tradition.
